title: Weaker Sterling Drives up Prime Central London Residential Market
text:
Despite unending Brexit uncertainty, the combination of a weaker sterling, pent-up demand and the stamp duty-related price adjustments is bolstering prime Central London markets, according to a report Wednesday.



The transaction volume in the area, which includes the most exclusive and expensive neighborhoods in the country, rose 11% year-over-year in September, according to Knight Frank’s London Residential Review.



The data only includes residential properties handled by the brokerage.



The EU has allowed the U.K. to delay its Brexit departure until Jan. 31. Meanwhile, Britain is holding a new election on Dec. 12.



“Irrespective of the political backdrop, transaction activity has been on an upward trajectory,” said Tom Bill, the brokerage’s head of residential research.

On average, prices in Prime Central London are now 14% lower than four years ago, which more than compensates for higher rates of stamp duty.



Starting April 2016, the U.K. raised the stamp duty by 3% on second homes over £40,000. For a £2 million property, that means a buyer has to pay an extra £60,000 in taxes.



Since then, many luxury buyers have adopted a wait-and-see attitude, which dampened the demand for prime properties, and sales prices fell consequently.



The price adjustment, combined with the favorable exchange rates for most overseas buyers, translates into a more than 25% discount in Prime Central London, Knight Frank said.



Average prices for existing homes in Prime Central London fell 3.9% in the year to September, the smallest decline in 12 months, according to the report.



The brokerage didn’t release concrete data for sales and prices.
